p:
Seasonal H3N2 epidemics consistently caused more clinically attended cases in older cohorts, while H1N1 caused a greater proportion of cases in young and middle-aged adults ( Figs 2, S1 and S2 ). These patterns were apparent whether we compared H3N2 epidemic age distributions with those caused by the pre-2009 seasonal H1N1 lineage, or with the post-2009 lineage. Observed patterns are consistent with the predicted effects of cohort-specific imprinting (
Fig 1 ), and with previously reported differences in age distribution of seasonal H1N1 and H3N2 incidence [ 12â€“ 14, 31]. See
Fig 2 for seasons where H1N1 and H3N2 co-circulated in substantial numbers, and
S1 and S2 Figs. for the entire dataset and alternate smoothing parameters.
